title: Capybara - Wikipedia
summary:
- The capybara (Hydrochoerus hydrochaeris) is the largest living rodent, native to South America, and can weigh between 35 to 66 kg (77 to 146 lb).
- Adult capybaras typically measure 106 to 134 cm (3.48 to 4.40 ft) in length and stand 50 to 62 cm (20 to 24 in) tall at the withers.
- They are highly social animals, often found in groups of 10-20, but can gather in larger groups of up to 100 during the dry season.
- Capybaras are herbivores, primarily grazing on grasses and aquatic plants, and are known to consume their own feces to aid digestion.
- Their maximum lifespan is about 8 to 10 years, but they usually live only 4 years in the wild due to predation from big cats and other predators.
- Capybaras are classified as "Least Concern" by the IUCN, with stable populations in most of their range, although hunting has impacted some areas.
- They have adapted well to urban environments and are often found in zoos and parks, where they can live up to 12 years in captivity.
- Capybaras have gained popularity in popular culture, becoming internet memes and symbols of class struggle in Argentina.

Takeaway: The capybara is a unique and sociable rodent, well-adapted to its environment and increasingly recognized in both wildlife conservation and popular culture.
